content.description: Quite fun edges similar to those on Betty Tendonblaster, but not quite as good! Rated .10a in the old guidebook, it's just not that hard.
content.location: Just right of Betty Tendonblaster, the route with an instructional two-bolt anchor at the base.

content.description: Intriguing movement on some strange holds. Probably my least favorite route here (although I've heard "Middle Route" is pretty bad too).
content.location: The furthest route right on the wall. Belay up in the 3rd class chimney.

content.description: Cruxy near the roof pull. In a sea of those great Rodeo patina edges, sometimes it's hard to see the often fundamental hidden pockets. Fun edge pulling above roof.
content.location: Starts just left of its tobacco bro Copenhagen.

climbs.name: Quickdraw McGraw
climbs.fa: Tom Turiano, Jim Kanzler, Wes Bunch

content.description: Fun climb characterized by vertical pockets at the powerful roof. A fairly long (but easy) run to the anchor from the last bolt. Rated .10a in the old Sotille guidebook. The roof is a fair bit burlier than that (I thought).
content.location: Just right of Alive in Wyoming.

content.description:
It starts on dirty low angle terrain before arriving at a large section of the roof. Pull over the roof on small, non-patina holds, continue up and right over the overlap, before meeting up with the upper few bolts of Redman.

This route is still bolted in a more old-school fashion. Just a heads up.
Shallow pockets, sloping holds, and moving left/right of bolts characterize this one. Fun and different holds than most of its Rodeo counterparts.
content.location: Just right of, you guessed it, Thelma.

content.description: Entertaining face climbing above the roof is the highlight of this route.  The climb begins with 30 feet of slab to the standard Rodeo roof move.  The final headwall to the anchors is thin and thought provoking.  Stay left of the upper bolts for the easiest passage.
content.location: The first climb right of the "step up" on the base trail (so it is BEFORE the step!).  Also right of the dead tree in the middle of the base.

content.description: Start up "8 Second Ride" for two bolts before cutting right up a line of rust-colored bolts, which were reinstalled by Greg Miles in 2016.
content.location: Shares start with 8 Second Ride before cutting right. Below lowest part of first roof.

content.description: Three different crux sections keep this climb interesting.  Save some energy for the finish! The first crux is just passing the small roof at the first bolt.  The next crux comes at midheight and involves thin, but positive crimps.  The final crux is just past the last bolt and is a difficult sequence of moves on sloping pockets.  The finishing moves make this climb a challenging onsite for the grade.
content.protection: 10 or 11 bolts. Cold shuts on top.
content.location: Third route from the left.  A little difficult to locate since there are two other routes immediately right of it.

content.description: Cruxiest moves at the bottom and top, with a somewhat burly roof pull at midheight. Fun!
content.location: Route located just left of the "Middle Route".

content.description: One of the better climbs at Rodeo.  A bouldery move off the ground gets you into 30 feet of slab climbing.  A difficult move over a roof leads to balancy moves to the next bolt.  Don't fall here!  Slightly spaced bolts up the headwall above get you to the anchor.
content.location: The first climb left of the dead tree at center of the trail along the base.   You can identify it by a low bolt protecting the opening moves.  It is also just left of the "step up" on the base trail.

content.description: The best 5.9 at Rodeo and the usual warmup.  The climb begins with 30 feet of slab, to a fun roof move, and then quality crimping and edging to the anchors.
content.location: The second climb to the right of the "step up" in the middle of the base trail.  About 15 feet to the right of this step.

content.description: Some 5.8 climbing takes you to the roof, where a loooooong reach to a suitcase handle jug allows passage over the roof.  5.9 climbing continues to the anchor.
content.location: The furthest left route on the wall. Keep walking left along the base until you can't walk any further.

content.description:
A fun moderate with somewhat spacey bolts. Feels similar to Bulldoggin', but bigger holds & less sustained.

Called 10 Second Ride and given .10c in the old guidebook.
content.location: If you've ever been on Bulldoggin' and noticed the squeeze job that's within arms reach (to your right) of you, that's 8 Second Ride.
